There exists infinitely many deficient numbers

type: {n | n.Deficient}.Infinite
name: Nat.infinite_deficient
docString: There exists infinitely many deficient numbers

Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even n ∨ Odd n
name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` being odd is equivalent to `n` not being even. In other words, a natural number is odd if and only if it is not even. Here, a number is considered odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some `k`, and a number is considered even if it can be written as `r + r` for some `r`.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Odd n ↔ ¬Even n
name: Nat.odd_iff_not_even
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` being odd is equivalent to `n` not being even. In other words, a natural number is odd if and only if it is not even. Here, a number is considered odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some `k`, and a number is considered even if it can be written as `r + r` for some `r`.

The zero function is odd.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {β : Type u_2} [inst : Neg α] [inst_1 : NegZeroClass β], Function.Odd fun x => 0
name: Function.Odd.zero
docString: The zero function is odd.

For every natural number `n`, the oddness of `n` and `n+1` are opposite.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), n.succ.bodd = !n.bodd
name: Nat.bodd_succ
docString: For every natural number `n`, the oddness of `n` and `n+1` are opposite.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, `n` is odd if and only if it is not even. In the context of a semiring, a number `n` is odd if there exists another number `k` such that `n` equals `2*k + 1`. On the other hand, a number `n` is even if there exists a number `r` such that `n` equals `r + r`. Therefore, this theorem establishes the mutually exclusive and exhaustive nature of odd and even numbers in the set of natural numbers.

type: ∀ {α : Sort u_1} {a b : α}, (a = b) = (b = a)
name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.4
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, `n` is odd if and only if it is not even. In the context of a semiring, a number `n` is odd if there exists another number `k` such that `n` equals `2*k + 1`. On the other hand, a number `n` is even if there exists a number `r` such that `n` equals `r + r`. Therefore, this theorem establishes the mutually exclusive and exhaustive nature of odd and even numbers in the set of natural numbers.

A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

name: Nat.odd_mod_four_iff
docString: A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

name: Nat.evenOddStrongRec

The L-function of an odd function vanishes at negative odd integers.

type: ∀ {N : ℕ} [inst : NeZero N] {Φ : ZMod N → ℂ}, Function.Odd Φ → ∀ (n : ℕ), ZMod.LFunction Φ (-(2 * ↑n) - 1) = 0
name: ZMod.LFunction_neg_two_mul_nat_sub_one
docString: The L-function of an odd function vanishes at negative odd integers.

The sum of the values of an odd function is 0.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_3} {β : Type u_4} [inst : AddCommGroup β] [inst_1 : NoZeroSMulDivisors ℕ β] [inst_2 : Fintype α]
  [inst_3 : InvolutiveNeg α] {f : α → β}, Function.Odd f → ∑ a : α, f a = 0
name: Function.Odd.sum_eq_zero
docString: The sum of the values of an odd function is 0.

In `Fin n`, all elements are odd for odd `n`,
otherwise an element is odd iff its `Fin.val` value is odd.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ} [inst : NeZero n] {k : Fin n}, Odd k ↔ Odd n ∨ Odd ↑k
name: Fin.odd_iff
docString:
In `Fin n`, all elements are odd for odd `n`,
otherwise an element is odd iff its `Fin.val` value is odd.

The infinite monadic lazy list of natural numbers.

type: {m : Type → Type} → [inst : Monad m] → MLList m ℕ
name: MLList.range

Any constant function is even.

Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

A product of finite numbers is still finite.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {s : Finset α} {f : α → ENNReal}, (∀ a ∈ s, f a < ⊤) → ∏ a ∈ s, f a < ⊤
name: ENNReal.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite.
